title: How to Care for an Echinocactus

steps.headline: Check what species of Echinocactus you have.
steps.description: Echinocactus grusonii, commonly known as the Golden Barrel Cactus, is the most widely cultivated species. There are a number of different forms and varieties of this species, but their care is essentially the same. However, if you have one of the other 5 more unusual species, these may require more specialised care.

steps.headline: Select the correct growing media.
steps.description: Loam-based potting compost is ideal, with some horticultural grit (small crushed stones) added to it for good drainage. Alternatively you could use proprietary cactus compost.

steps.headline: Find an appropriate growing position.
steps.description: Because this species prefers full sun, you could choose to grow it on a bright windowsill or in a heated greenhouse in cooler climates. The minimum temperature for this species is between 5 to 10 degrees Celsius. A south-facing or west-facing position is ideal. Well-drained soil is very important - wet soil causes rotting.

steps.headline: Know how often to water.
steps.description: You should water moderately when in growth (from spring to autumn). Give no water at all during the dormant season (winter).

steps.headline: Feed your plant.
steps.description: Apply a balanced liquid fertiliser up to three times throughout the growing season (spring to autumn).

steps.headline: Recognise, prevent & control pests.
steps.description: Mealybugs can be a problem. You can recognise an infestation as fluffy white wax on the cactus stem and a sticky residue from the honeydew that the insects excrete. Prevent mealybugs by keeping new plants in isolation from your existing plants for a month or so, watching your new plants carefully for signs of infestation. Don't buy plants showing signs of infestation. Regularly remove dead plant material from the greenhouse/growing space where the mealybugs can hide. Where you have a mealybug infestation in a greenhouse, you can use a biological control, a ladybird called Cryptolaemus montrouzieri. These need fairly high temperatures to work, so are only really useful during the summer months or in a greenhouse that is heated 24/7 in colder periods. Alternatively, try painting over the white fluffy wax with a little olive oil, which will suffocate the mealybugs.

steps.headline: Propagate by seed.
steps.description: Fill a plant pot with loam-based compost that has had grit added to it, or alternatively a proprietary cactus compost. Firm and level the surface. Thinly scatter the seed over the surface of the compost. Cover with a thin layer of vermiculite or fine grit. Cover the pot with a sheet of glass or a plastic bag and place on a warm windowsill, or in a greenhouse. Water whenever the compost starts to feel dry, but don't overwater or the seeds will rot. Seedlings should start to appear within a few weeks, but be patient, sometimes they can take longer. The following spring, your young cactus plants should be ready to transplant into their own individual pots.
